citations.narrative:
The maximum number of animals authorized for the facility’s current license is 100, but the APHIS official counted over
260 regulated animals during inspection.
The USDA license authorizes a specific number of animals to ensure the facility is capable of providing care for that
number of animals.
licensee must obtain a new license before any change resulting in more than the authorized number of animals on hand
at any single point in time during the period of licensure. The licensee must maintain no more than the maximum number
of animals that their USDA license allows.
To be corrected by Oct. 1, 2024.

No artificial cooling was supplied to the rabbits (8) housed outdoors during the inspection when atmospheric air
temperatures were 93 to 95 degrees F and in-cage temperatures were recorded at 94.5 degrees.
Rabbits are sensitive to excessive heat. Lack of additional cooling when temperatures are above 90 degrees F can cause
discomfort and stress, heat stress/stroke, illness and death.
Additional cooling must be provided when temperatures are above 90 degrees F.
Correct by 8/5/2024.

In the rabbit (8) area, excessive flies were seen concentrated in the litter pans under the rabbits.
Excessive flies can cause distress and illness and disease in rabbits and can be an indication of inadequate cleaning and
sanitation.
An effective program to control insects and other pests must be established and maintained.
To be corrected by 8/24/2024.

The water tubs in pens along eastern side of property for the cavy (6), capybaras (2) pigs (2) goat kids (8) were murky
and dirty and contained large amounts of floating debris and fecal material. The capybara (2) large stock tank's water was
extremely green and cloudy with floating debris and had not been cleaned in over two weeks according to the licensee.
Contaminated water can be unpalatable and unhealthy for the animals leading to ill thrift, illness and disease. All water
containers must be kept clean and sanitary.

In the parakeet (150) walk in aviary, one round wooden perch (~ 4 feet long) and one branch (~ 5 feet long) were provided
for perching. Approximately 35 birds total were able to perch on the provided surfaces, resulting in over 100 birds clinging
to the cage edges and wires.
Inappropriate perching surfaces (size, material, and sufficient space) can result in discomfort and foot injuries to the birds.
Perches must be available that are appropriate to the species and of sufficient number, size, shape , strength, texture and
placement to comfortably hold all the birds in the primary enclosure at the same time.
To be corrected by 8/14/2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
No Environmental Enrichment Plan has been established for the 150 parakeets and 2 emus.
A lack of species appropriate and varied environmental enrichment can lead to boredom, abnormal or stereotypic
behaviors, or other health or psychological problems.
A species appropriate environmental enrichment plan must be developed, documented and followed to ensure the
psychological well-being of the birds by providing activities, materials, and social interactions that allow species-typical
activity and behavior.
The plan must address at a minimum social grouping, environment enrichment, and special considerations. The plan
must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with
currently accepted professional standards. This plan must be made available to APHIS upon request.
To be corrected by 8/30/2024.

In the parakeet (150) walk in aviary only two water bowls were present. One was dry with crusted food debris on bottom
and sides. The other bowl contained scummy water, with food waste and flies floating on the surface.
Dirty water bowls and insufficient water can lead to stress and illness in the birds.
Water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitized as often as necessary to keep them clean and free of contamination.
Group housed birds must have multiple water receptacles to ensure all birds have access to sufficient water.
To be corrected by 8/10/2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.1(b)(2)(i) 
   
Requirements and application 
The maximum number of animals authorized for the facility’s current license is 100, but the APHIS official counted over 
260 regulated animals during inspection.  
The USDA license authorizes a specific number of animals to ensure the facility is capable of providing care for that 
number of animals.  
licensee must obtain a new license before any change resulting in more than the authorized number of animals on hand 
at any single point in time during the period of licensure. The licensee must maintain no more than the maximum number 
of animals that their USDA license allows.  
To be corrected by Oct. 1, 2024. 
3.52(a) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
No artificial cooling was supplied to the rabbits (8) housed outdoors during the inspection when atmospheric air 
temperatures were 93 to 95 degrees F and in-cage temperatures were recorded at 94.5 degrees.  
Rabbits are sensitive to excessive heat. Lack of additional cooling when temperatures are above 90 degrees F can cause 
discomfort and stress, heat stress/stroke, illness and death. 
Additional cooling must be provided when temperatures are above 90 degrees F. 
Correct by 8/5/2024. 
3.56(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
In the rabbit (8) area, excessive flies were seen concentrated in the litter pans under the rabbits. 
Excessive flies can cause distress and illness and disease in rabbits and can be an indication of inadequate cleaning and 
sanitation. 
An effective program to control insects and other pests must be established and maintained. 
 
To be corrected by 8/24/2024.

3.130  Repeat
   
Watering. 
The water tubs in pens along eastern side of property for the cavy (6), capybaras (2) pigs (2) goat kids (8) were murky 
and dirty and contained large amounts of floating debris and fecal material. The capybara (2) large stock tank's water was 
extremely green and cloudy with floating debris and had not been cleaned in over two weeks according to the licensee. 
Contaminated water can be unpalatable and unhealthy for the animals leading to ill thrift, illness and disease. All water 
containers must be kept clean and sanitary. 
3.153(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In the parakeet (150) walk in aviary, one round wooden perch (~ 4 feet long) and one branch (~ 5 feet long) were provided 
for perching. Approximately 35 birds total were able to perch on the provided surfaces, resulting in over 100 birds clinging 
to the cage edges and wires. 
Inappropriate perching surfaces (size, material, and sufficient space) can result in discomfort and foot injuries to the birds. 
Perches must be available that are appropriate to the species and of sufficient number, size, shape , strength, texture and 
placement to comfortably hold all the birds in the primary enclosure at the same time. 
To be corrected by 8/14/2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
No Environmental Enrichment Plan has been established for the 150 parakeets and 2 emus.  
A lack of species appropriate and varied environmental enrichment can lead to boredom, abnormal or stereotypic 
behaviors, or other health or psychological problems.  
A species appropriate environmental enrichment plan must be developed, documented and followed to ensure the 
psychological well-being of the birds by providing activities, materials, and social interactions that allow species-typical 
activity and behavior. 
The plan must address at a minimum social grouping, environment enrichment, and special considerations. The plan 
must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with 
currently accepted professional standards. This plan must be made available to APHIS upon request. 
To be corrected by 8/30/2024. 
3.156 
   
Watering 
In the parakeet (150) walk in aviary only two water bowls were present. One was dry with crusted food debris on bottom 
and sides. The other bowl contained scummy water, with food waste and flies floating on the surface. 
Dirty water bowls and insufficient water can lead to stress and illness in the birds. 
Water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitized as often as necessary to keep them clean and free of contamination. 
Group housed birds must have multiple water receptacles to ensure all birds have access to sufficient water. 
To be corrected by 8/10/2024.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
